Maybe it wasn't clean or the workers in the back don't wash their hands, I'm not sure. 

Usually I let things slide if I just had an upset stomach, but if I puke, you're gonna get a 1 star.
author: Clinton L.

description: Service can be a little rough, but the food is top notch. Their shrimp and crab rank high among the finest i ever had.
author: Maisel C.

description:
Service - almost nonexistent but efficient enough
Atmosphere - loud Chinese people, mostly tai-shan like the staff
Food - good authentic greasy food
Price - cheap!

This place is definitely setup more for large families or groups. If you have never been to Hong Kong or a large city in China where you have to get down and dirty to get some good cheap food AND clean your own plates/utensils, this place probably ain't for you. And if you don't speak Chinese, it'll be hard to order.

Yeah, it's not the cleanest or best tasting, but very decent for what you pay. I usually come here with my family for some fast, cheap, food close to home. Our whole dinner with 6 entrees and a soup cost less than what we spent when we went to dim sum at an average restaurant!
author: Linda C.

description:
I love this hole in the wall! 

They have a preset menu for parties starting at 3 people. They allow substitutions depending on similar pricing. 

Soup is always warm, full of veggies, tofu, and beef (this is the one I order) 
Fried Flounder is always crispy with just the right amount of sauce 
Chicken with Ginger sauce is always moist and tasty 
Fried Spicy Salty Shrimp is crispy and oh so flavorful 
Mustard Greens are crunchy but carry the flavor from the garlic it's sauteed in 

I could keep going but I'm getting withdrawals. YUMMMMMM 
Great Food!!!
author: J-nine I.

description:
The deep fried flounder from a number of decent reviews was a huge disappointment. It was batter-flavored (tasted like flour paste) and really gross with a stink that permeated the table. It made me lose my appetite for the rest of the dishes that came with the 5-item meal for $23. I also don't understand why they put THREE deep-fried items on the same menu, plus a very oily vegetable dish.

The only good thing was how cheap it all was, so we could just ignore the fish. The fried pork chops were pretty good, as well as the salt/pepper shrimp, but god was that fish disgusting... 

Wait, did I remember to mention the fried fish?
author: Winnie K.

description:
I got the Chow Fun with black been sauce o_O try it you will be able to leave with some change!
I go for take out since the atmosphere is usually crowded.
author: Matteo C.

description: Cheap chinese food for lunch. 5 buck specials for a lot of different rice places and noodles. Fast and speedy. Being Asian, there could be better chinese food, so 3 stars.
author: Jason H.

description:
This is one of my favorite regular take-out spots when I used to live around the corner from Taraval.  You really only eat-in if you wanna amuse your friends with tacky decor, large-zany family watchin, and to get  ideas on the latest-cutting-edge asian hairstyles for men.

Yesterday ordered the mongolian beef- loaded with onions, jalapeno, and green onion-YUM, walnut honey prawns- WOW!, garlic bokchoy- INDEED!, and Hong Kong style crispy noodles with shrimp- YES!  All of the dishes are distinctive Chinese flavors- known as Hakka, which represents a minor ethnic group in China known for their vagrant ways and the Hakka cuisine really reflects this.

A spot like this is what makes SF so rare in finding such unique flavors and for such incredible prices-- the 3 of us only spent $30 and had choke leftovers--crazy yeah!  Receiving fresh, tasty oranges and the warm, red bean, tapioca dessert are incentives of dining in.
author: omar b.

description: I came here with my boyfriend after work and i was craving some chinese food and found this place through yelp. It was so busy when we came in. I didn't like the fact we had to share a table with strangers. So awkward. We ordered magolian beef and seafood chow mein. I thought it was so good but i guess i was wrong because the whole ride home, I was feeling sick. Damn you MSG.
author: Janice V.

description:
You want to test someone's mental and emotional fortitude?  Take him or her to this restaurant.  Cheap delicious comfort food, but not for the faint of heart.  If greasy chopsticks, sticky tables and flies bother you, then don't go to this place.  As an ABC, SF native, I've grown up on food and places like this, so it doesn't bother me at all.

I'm sure this is the place that all of the kung fu students go to after a tough class.
author: Jane C.

description: Greasy but tasty... Dirty dive but cheap... surly service and it doesn't look like the place gets cleaned often, but again the food wasn't half bad... it's like a 1000 other Chinese places in SF that tend to cater to a predominantly Chinese crowd... that's generally a good sign for me so we overlooked the squalor of the place...
author: David H.

description:
This is your typical chinese hole in the wall but the food here is outstanding.  One of my favorite restaurants.

I like the spicy salted squid (calamari), Crispy meat stuffed tofu, seafood and tofu soup, double mushroom chicken, spicy salted pork ribs, oysters with black beans sauce, etc.
author: Serena H.

description:
Went here a couple of years back.

Heard horror stories and witnessed things that were etched into my mind.  No matter what, I would remember this restaurant name. 

Moment we sat down, I noticed a lot of flies around. Some waiters were swatting them with their fly swatters, and you can hear the electric crackle every time they made a hit.

The bathroom was dark, the skylight looked out of place. I was waiting for a flood of bugs to attack me.

And OH MY GOSH. A waiter accidentally knocked over toothpicks and was picking them up and shoving them back in to the container.

Food was okay.
author: Christin A.

description: Came here on several occasions for traditional "hakka" dishes. The braised pork belly is almost one of the best I've tried in the bay area...a second close to Capital restaurant in Chinatown. Everything else is pretty average. The food here is dirt cheap and portions are huge but the trade-off is the crummy condition of the restaurant. I've been in porta-pottys that appear cleaner than this place.
author: Eric L.

description:
I have this place on speed dial on my cell. I can't account for their ambiance or uncleanliness, since I usually order two dishes from them: chicken chow fun (with vegetables $3.75) and chicken fried rice ($4.75). The chicken fried rice isn't on the menu but if you ask for it in Chinese they'll give it to you.

The fried rice is YUM! I don't think I've tried a restaurant-style fried rice that tastes this good before and their chicken chow fun...lots of gravy so if you're ordering take out, be careful with your drive home because the sauce does spill out of the carton! These are the only two dishes I've tried and every time I order them, I have a happy belly!
author: Janel Y.

description:
Five stars for cheap Chinese? Um, yeah, especially when there are plenty of steamed tofu and chicken options on the menu, and the tofu dish I went with was enough food for lunch AND dinner.

Szechuan Taste doesn't excel in ambiance (unless you like the Energy 92.7 background music), just cheap, healthy, good Chinese.
author: Jason B.

description: Honey walnnut prawns are AWESOME. Its cheap, but the service is horrible and the restaurant is freeeeeezing. But you get what you pay for, and for $22 for two people with plenty of leftovers, its so worth it. Go for the Honey Walnut Prawns, not the service.
author: Stephanie W.

description: First time experience at this restaurant !  typically, there was no one there. how exciting! i thought the cleanness from the outside was really clean until i got there. the food seems like it wasn't long enough. we ordered 4 dishes and it was already done by the time we got to talk. service was o.k. but the kitchen need some special cleaning. it's sort of a mess in the there.
author: Miranda T.

description: This is the place my parents order for dinner when they're lazy to cook or if it's just one of those days when nobody knows what to eat for dinner. We usually get the noodle and rice dishes to go, and for 4 orders, it's only around $20, depending on what you order.  Perfect if you're craving cheap and mom-style cooking in the Sunset district. :)
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE this place!

I discovered it on January 1st 2005. There was nothing to eat at the house so my guy friend and I started walking down Taraval (I used to live on 16th ave. & Santiago) and lo and behold there it was: Szechuan Taste. A hole in the wall, if you must.

The seating arrangements are fascinating to me.
They have long tables and round tables. When you sit, you are most likely sharing the table with other people who may come in later or who are already there.

The food is super cheap. We both had three courses and paid less than $15. Tip included.

They take a wee bit to take your order, but the food comes right away.

And even though they don't deliver (which is why I only give them 4*s.) I've called while riding the L on West Portal, and by the time I'm on 19th my food is ready and waiting :)

The staff is friendly and helpful.

The place could use a makeover.

Overall, Good food for very little money. Yay!
author: Miss E.

description:
0.5 stars cleanliness (big turn off)
3 stars for the good tasting food
3 stars for the big portions
3 stars for the value if you order the family meals

Came here 3-4 times before...food is good but they really gotta clean up the appearance....Overall 2.5 stars
author: sonya h.

description:
This place is GREAT, CHEAP, and FRIENDLY...well most of them, I have been going here for half my life now and the owners know me very well, Vivian usually the lady covering the cashier and her husband, the short chinese guy that wears a black vest...I forgot his name...but anyways this place is one of my favorite places to go for chinese, its cheap and good, even though its not very clean or artistic and I highly advice you to use the restroom before you go here...lol.  

I have never received food poisoning here ever in my life, although it may look dirty it hasn't lead to any illness or whatsoever.

Ordering...again food is cheap so you can be order abundantly but still pay under 20 dollars for 3 people..the mongolian beef here is one of my favorites about 6.50, and the calamari is only 4.50 so try it!  Then you can order any greens and then to start is hot n sour soup which is one of the best i've ever had...whatever you order here you cant go wrong, from seafood to beef to fish to chicken, whatever you like they got it!!! Definitely recommend this place to ANYONE!
author: Genesis K.

description:
I come here with my buddies for the Salt and Pepper Spare Ribs over Rice and that is it. It's good...once every two to three months. The restaurant itself...well, don't expect too much. It's dirty, cheap and filled with construction workers and painters in the afternoon lunch period! At night...wait a sec, I don't go there for dinner. Ha! It's not much, but it's a typical cheap Chinese restaurant. Bleh. 

Eat here if you're desperately hungry (as in 40 days and 40 nights of hunger). Otherwise, walk around the corner for Seniore's.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
10 or more items on the family menu for 10 people for $118?  You don't get anything cheaper than this anywhere else.  That included soup, mushroom and mustard green, beef and pok choi, huge fried fish, salt bake chicken, salt and pepper prawns, house special spareribs, 10 whole steam oyster with black bean sauce, crab with ginger and green onion, fried rice, and dessert.  All those for $118?  on big plates? in San Francisco? common, if you come with big groups, give them a try.

The place is not very clean, I agree.  The service here is  better than most Chinese restaurants, they are not too attentive, but they get what you ask for right away and plus, they aren't rude.   The food quality isn't bad at all.  Food came out really fast, the 1st item came out about 15 min after we ordered, the last item came out about 20 min after the 1st one.  If you have big group, want cheap food, want good food, not too picky about the cleanliness, not care too much about service, this is definitely the place for you.  My family has no patient, they don't want to wait, this is perfect for us.
author: Lily K.

description: favorite family place for 18yrs. Honey Walnut Prawns!!!
author: Drea P.

description: been eating at this place since high school days which 10+ years... just love it... they always have there lunch special for under $4 spare ribs over rice... just two of use and we do 3 order and were full every time... oh yeah they special lunch/dinner sets which start off $17 but now its $19 the last time i was out there... come with rice, salt pepper prawns, salt spare ribs, soup, yui choi, and deep fryed founder.... all for about $25 if you order two soda too... bang for the bucks if your hungry!
author: JessePanda C.

description: Been eating here since I was 5. The sliced pork, kung pao chicken, and honey walnut prawns are amazing. Also, get the black bean oysters and the fried rice. I love the hole-in-the-wall location of the place. Btw, the restrooms are still not good and sometimes there are many flies inside. Overall, awesome place. :D
author: Chris R.

description: Ordered an Lemon Chicken. Hardly find any chicken. Pepper salt pork, no pepper taste and pork was more crisp than jerky. Also had walnut prawns, at least that was edible, but walnuts were old and prawns were not deveined properly. Basically, couldn't finish my dinner. Not going here again.
author: David H.

description: PLEASE DONT EAT HERE! I went here on Christmas with my family and the food was AWFUL! I dont have much of a problem with BAD chinese food, because there is so much out there, but the problem is the place is DIRTY!!!! My son had food poisoning the morning after we ate there. My dad and I both had stomach aches. I can't blame them for myself and my dad, because we ate other food that day,but that was the only solid meal my son had that day. I'm going to file a compliant on their restaurant, if anyone else have a problem with the restaurant I think you should too.
author: Crystina L.

description: We ordered these dishes for dinner last night.  Shrimp with steamed tofu was very tasty.  Peking duck - eh...have had better.  Deep fried calamari was very good, crunchy, not chewy, but tasted heavy (like fried in older oil).  Beef chow fun was very good.  Sweet and sour pork was standard.  Whole rock cod was very good, very tender.  Fried wontons were meh.... Kung Pao Chicken was ok as well.  Westlake Beef Soup was very tasty.  Bean dessert soup was ok as well.  Overall, very tasty food, pretty salty though.  Service is difficult, hard to get the people's attention.  Go here for the food, not so much the service.
author: June W.

description:
I really loved this place, i went a few times and had a great time, had decent food, but recently, it has been super dirty with lots of flies inside, and really mediocre food.
I'm over it.
Can anyone recommend a different chinese food restaurant close by?
author: Taylor C.

description:
I have to say I was a bit suspicious when my coworkers told me there was a good chinese food restaurant down a couple streets. I had been victim to the bad foods of taraval such as Ha Noi Bistro, Mings Cafe, and KFC, so my expectations for this place were pretty low, however i was told that it was CHEEP!!!! SFSU student making his way on loans and a  bag boy salary can't just drop 7 dollars like it's nothing. No I needed to stretch my dollar. Apparently the food here was ridiculously cheep so I was like "ok Cindy I'll check it out."
So the next day I am feeling the groans and growls of a 1.5 meal a day diet. I look in my wallet. 8 dollars. I could've easily rode the bus up to to the Ha Noi Bistro and Order like... 4 orders of white rice, or gone down to my dining commons for some nasty food, but I decide to ride up to taraval to check this place out... and buy some almond milk at my store.
OMFG! I walk in and the place is a mess. Paint is faint, door seems unhinged, and dilapidated furnishings are ubiquitous. I've seen worse.
I grab a menu and begin to read. Everything sounded pretty good... and then i scrolled my eyes over to the prices.
OMFG! I POOPED BRICKS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
4.50 for some stirfried rice?!?!?!?!?!?!?!?! how much am i getting a spoonful. I was in shock. I call the waiter over and say... "Ni Hao" and he looks at me grudgingly for failing to pronounce the standard manderin greeting properly. I ask him about the price/portion ratio. I ask should i get an order of white rice alongside it? He looks at with wide eyes. Maybe his english wasn't so good, or maybe he was amazed that I didn't think i'd get enough.
OMFG!!!! 6 dollars and 10 minutes later... I POOP MOAR BRICKS!!!!!!!!!!
I have too much food!
I ordered carry out... and man were those orders potent. I can still smell them even now... but boy were they good. I get home and open my boxes and grab my chopsticks. I take up a some of the vegetable stir fry with my chops ... rice and egg falling out, my grip not quite strong enough to hold a huge bite... but man.... i chew and chew and chewed... and then i swallowed.... and then.... I POOPED MOAR BRICKS!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!111

OMFG this place is sooo good and so cheep. I love it! I love it! I LOVE IT!
author: Israel C.

description: Too bad Yelp doesn't allow a negative star rating 'cause this hole in the wall deserves one!! Man, this is a prime example of the main restaurants that should be inspected every month by the health department. There were literally little flies flying all around our food (makes me sick just thinking about it!). Yeah, the food given is abundant but it screams a shockful of MSG! I don't even want to know what the kitchen looks like!! Please go elsewhere....
author: La C.

description: Foodwise, it's good and cheap Chinese food.  Two to three can eat for less than $20.  Got a larger party, 7-10, $100 should feed everyone and still have food to take home.  For decor and cleanliness, it's literally the hole-in-the-wall place that you've always heard of.   I came here with my friends for a college graduation party...before they had remodeled.  It was darkly lit, yet packed.  They removed some of the fixtures and made it more light and airy...but it's still a dive.  Go to eat, not to use the restroom...unless it's an emergency.
author: JeFF T.

description: My mom took us here for a family dinner.  The food looked great and the place look pretty dirty.   I was still a teen when she took us here.  I remember eating tons of sweet and sour pork because it was so good.  Later at nite I think I had food poisoning and missed school I think.
author: John F.

description: I guess this place would be fine if you love meat. But I don't like meat much but chicken so yep. Isn't much chicken around here, and definately not much vegetarian selections.
author: Katherine C.

description: I love this place.  Okay, yes it isn't the cleanest place.  I think it might be cleaner eating in my backyard...off the ground.  The food is good and cheap.  Whole crabs for under $10.  In their defense it used to be worse until they remodeled a few years back.  I can't explain it but on a few instances I wasn't feeling well during the day and after I ate there I came out feeling great.  Some ancient Chinese medicinal properties?  Or maybe my natural flora is strengthened in there.  We've been seated in the back on the way to the restrooms which wasn't great.  Hey, I've been in worse bathrooms in Asia so nothing here makes me squirm.
author: Brad K.

description: I survive another visit and didn't get sick.  Lots of empty resturant on Taraval and we walk passed many with empty stomach. ST is a full house.  This time I don't see any critters and the ladies at the next table said this place has gotten clean.  My friend didn't think so and complains about the table being sticky.  I said shut up, where can you find a menu with $4.75 items on them.  $4.50 rice plate humm.
author: Mar H.

description:
I've been coming here since 1993. This place hasn't changed one bit. The crispy stuffed tofu still costs $3.50. (Truly amazing. Even Wrigley's Spearmint has gotten more expensive in fourteen years.) You can still get dinner for three here - and leftovers to last a week - for under $20. The waiters, all twenty-something HK ragamuffins, still slap each other on the butt when they pass. Okay, the decor is a little different. When I was in high school the owners removed the faux-ski-lodge wall panels. But besides this I wouldn't have it any other way.

I have a hundred stories to tell about this place. One time when I was in college my family took my roommate here. Being from Boston, he hadn't tried much authentic Chinese food before, but he came away a fan of ST. (He didn't comment, though, on our table in a narrow section next to the restrooms - or the constant stream of patrons who bumped into our table on their way.)  On a recent visit with my mother, the joint was packed and we were seated at the same table as a young Caucausian couple. The man, an Irish emigre, apparently had never had Chinese food before; he asked his companion, a fetching Russian girl, what chow mein was. The girl asked the waiter about an item on the menu. Following ST custom, the waiter responded, "Very good choice!" Five minutes later, a sumptuous plate of fried rice came for the gentleman, and for the devushka: a small dish of cold gelatinous offal. The Russian asked her friend to share the food. His reply: "No bloody way I'm eating that!"

When Oprah talks about comfort food, she means a bucket of fried chicken. When I talk about comfort food, I mean a plate of fried salt and pepper pork chops at Szechuan Taste. If you want service and ambience go to Tommy Toy's. If you want the first choice in the Sunset for Chinese food chosen by contractors on their lunch break, Filipino families after church, and multi-generational households of Chinese Americans, take the L line to Szechuan Taste.
author: William L.

description: i came here last night for dinner with a group of 11 people.  They offer meal plans for large groups of 8 - 10+ people, which offer a variety of meats, seafood and veggies. The salt and peppered spareribs here are my personal favorite.  If you are a person who need some space between people ... this is not your restaurant. The space here is extremely packed, but they do accommodate to large groups. The crab was okay. And the oysters looked delicious, but I gave that to my boyfriend. The noise level here is extremely loud, so you can only hear people on your left and right. So seat yourself next to a person who you plan to talk to the most ... the one great thing about this restaurant is that they still offer tapioca dessert. It comes with the meal packages, but I do not know of any restaurants that still offer them.
author: Jen P.

description:
this place was recommended by my korean friend, raving about how cheap the food is.

first time i came here wanting some chow fun, but they said they were out.

second time the classmates and i came for a friends birthday lunch cuz she wanted chicken fried rice. the 10 of us shared pork belly with preserved cabbage, honey walnut prawns, garlic spinach, df sandab, salt-pepper shrimp, chicken fried rice, and more i just forgot what.

everything was going well until we asked for a refill of steamed rice and found a fly in the rice. the girls immediately lost their appetites, and the guys just ate around it, hahaha

service is nice, helps if you speak chinese or bring a chinese friend to order
author: David D.

description: This spot is real hood!  But the food is real good!!!! Best walnut prawns ever, no mayo!  Great reasonable seafood.  Just BYOFS, bring your own fly swatter.
author: sonia m.

description: Came here once with my friend for lunch . We had the eggplant and the chicken pot or whatever it is called . Both were pretty decent . Good place to go for a cheap lunch but the place is kind of filfthy ..
author: Eileen L.

description: Great authentic Chinese food. Really great prices too...they have a unbeatable lunch special for $3.50 that includes your choice of dish with rice and soup. I recommend the salty spicy squid ($3.50) and the salty spicy spareribs($4). The plates are big and really tasty...whenever I go during lunch time, I always see construction workers on lunch breaks and along with families and singles. Not the cleanest place, but the food makes up for it
author: Jessica h.

description: This place is so close to my house.. yay! So... this place is not all that clean inside.. BUT.. the food is good! The clams in black bean sauce, crab, salt and pepper spareribs and sweet and sour pork YUM! My family has been getting food from here for as long as i can remember! Oh yes and the prices aren't too bad either.. parking sucks just because its on 19th ave. -_-;; well.. good thing its within walking distance for me! ^_^
author: Heather C.

description:
note: I can only speak for their take-out (so far).. 

one day after work I was really craving some chow fun and stopped by here on the way home to pick up dinner. I walk proudly thru the tables to the back register, announce my order, only to be told that they were out of pho.

what. THE. PHO. dude.

how can you be out of pho! I still wanted some chinese food so I decided to get a mongolian beef rice plate.. $4.90 w/tax. DAMN that's like cheaper than mcdonalds. it was a whole lot of food, but my fat ass finished the whole thing, when I easily could've saved half for the next day. anyhow, I'm itchin' to go back to try their kung pao chicken now and still gotta get my chow fun.
author: Jennie L.

description:
1. Tasty Hakka food.
2. Cheap
3. Greasy
4. Chairs, tables, floors are sticky from grease
5. Order Salty salt & pepper spareribs, yang chow fried rice, and their chow fun.  ($20. Dinner for 3)


I used to go a lot.  I mean A Lot.  2x a day sometimes.  I even went after a workout.  What a waste of a workout.  They have good food.  The taste is not really consistent because they have different cooks that cooks things differently sometimes.  But, it taste good and it is cheap with a big C.

This restaurant used to be owned by someone else back maybe 10 years ago.  It was really stinky and sticky back then.  It smelled like cat urine.  Now, believe it or not, it is 5x as clean.  Food is good, and service is good.  I don't know how, but the service is good.  I don't get it.  It is better then other classier restaurants. 

A bit of advice, order take out.  You will feel more comfortable eating your food.
author: Christopher C.

description: decent to-go place.  lower your expectation and you should be satisfied.
author: Sydney L.

description: My regular go-to for Chinese. Clientele largely Asian. Service fast but frantic. Don't expect subtlety here in decor, service, atmosphere. Wildly vibrant paint and a faint aura of grunge, but sanitary enough. But the food is great, if you stay away from all the predictable stuff like chicken broccoli. Get the whole fried sand dab, or the steamed oysters, or the very cheap shrimp in egg custard. Delicious. Tip: Look around and see what the Asians are having. (It may not be on the menu.) Point and click, and the waiters will  bring it. Guilty pleasure: Walnut prawns, in something that looks like mayonnaise. What could it be?
author: Antonio P.

description:
This has been one of my parents favorite dineout places.  Abundant portions of food and cheap prices!  I have to admit, the ambience need a lot of makeover....especially the bathroom (Don't go in there unless you REALLY have to!)  But the food and prices makes up the difference.  

Where would you find a 5 item dinner for $18.  It's enough to feed over 4 ppl.  (Minced beef soup; fried prawns; mustard greens; fried flounder; bejing spareribs, and dessert - Mango tapioca & orange).

If not the set dinner menu, there's always the separate items for $3.50.  If you can read chinese (I can bare read) they also offer some good items plastered all over the walls in chinese.

Good food, good prices
author: Gary Y.

description: 6 adults ate here for lunch today.  Total cost $25 (including tax!).  20 dishes for $4.50 each.  Huge portions.  We all came out really full and even had leftovers which me and my sister are enjoying for dinner right now.  Yes, the decor is a bit dirty and bland, but those are the type of restaurants with the best food and its cheap!  They don't even charge for rice (for lunch at least)!
author: Erika C.

description:
We had dinner here last night for a family dinner.  The restaurant was about half full.  The service at this restaurant was not good, probably worse than the average Chinese restaurant.  The waiter simply ignored you so you would have to call or wave your hands to get any service.  The food came out really quick though.  But I think there was a reason because the chef simply deep fried all the meat or seafood dishes as a first step.  I could see and taste it.  They lemon chicken was really dry because of the deep fry.   All dishes we ordered taste okay but they were way too greasy for me, even the vegetable dishes.   I can a layer of oil at the bottom of my vegetable.    The crab was also deep fried before seasoning so it kinda ruin the freshness of the crab meat.   I was not hugely disappointed because the price is very cheap and I did not expect greatness for the price they charged.  I also like the steam egg and lamb clay pot.  They tasted good and not as greasy as other dishes.
In summary, I felt the restaurant was okay but I probably won't come back just because I don't like the amount of oil they put in my food.
author: Ben c.

description: Nothing great, just good Hakka and Szechuan cuisine with friendly service in a clean no frills atmosphere such as all sunset restaurants.  The service is very friendly and the prices are rock bottom.  I love the TV with the Cantonese programing; not that I can speak a lick as I'm Caucasian, but nevertheless it adds character.  The pot stickers are small yet delectable crispy golden morsiles with a perfect ground pork, cabbage, and ginger filling; perfect topped with a little sweet & sour sauce.  The chicken corn soup is large as are all the portions; plan on taking leftovers home.!  The soup is a large bowl of creamed corn, bits of chicken with a bit of grizzle yet still pretty good in a thick yet light broth.  The Mongolian beef is tender with onions and carrots over crispy rice noodles in a spicy chili garlic sauce that will pack enough punch to wake up your tastebuds yet not clear your sinuses.  The seafood chow mein, though a little oily tasting, was still worth it with soft noodles, fresh vegetables, prawns, scallops, and squid; it would have been cool if they would have had the yee mein.  The steamed rice is firm not soggy.  The tea is wonderful as are the fresh oranges for dessert.  So, for excellent Hakka & Szechuan cuisine at rock bottom prices in a clean no frills atmosphere with friendly service, Szechuan Taste cannot be beat.  Keep up the good work guys.!
author: Brian S.

description: Really doesn't even deserve one star.  I don't even know why it's still in business.  I pass by the area from time to time and I am surprised that people actually continue to eat there.  I ate there once for someone's birthday dinner and never came back.  Basically the food was pretty good, I'm not going to lie.  However, the restroom was filthy.  All of the toilets overflowed and there was water all-over the floor.  There was no soap dispensers or soap in the bathroom.  I find that disturbing especially after I saw one of the employees use the restroom before me and then washed her hands without using soap.  To top it all off, there was a roach in the take-out box.  Disgusting!  never again.  I heard stories about the place afterwords.  If I knew it would be that unsanitary, I would have never attended the dinner party.  An ex-coworker of mine ate there a year after and also complained because a roach fell from the ceiling and onto his plate.  I really want this nasty place shut down.  Don't eat here!
author: Jacquelynne S.

description:
excellent and real Cantonese style food
(not Szechuan style);

The price is great!

I have been the place during the last 10 yrs, when I visit SF during the weekends.

And I have recommended many Cantonese friends to this place, and they all like it!
author: Allen C.

description: This is the place to go to for a huge and inexpensive meal, take out or sit down.  There is no question - their salt and pepper pork chops (over rice to go) is a favorite of many.  They have several LARGE tables - many families drop by for dinner.  The portions are large, service is fast, food is tasty - excellent value for the money.  Keep in mind you are not paying for 5 star accommodations and you'll be well satisfied.  I only wish they stayed open later than 9:30pm.
author: Antonio E.

description: Kind of your typical Chinese hole in the wall. I give it credit because places like these ensure me that decent Chinese food still exists and that I shouldn't lose faith in Chinese Food (i.e. P.F Chang and Panda Express). I've lived in the neighborhood for most of my life and my family regulars this place like every other month. Our favorite dishes are clams in black bean sauce, this deep fried fish (if you go you can see a lot of people getting it), this steamed fish, some soup with scallops(sorry for my vagueness in menu items, I can't recall the names of the dishes on top of my head), and fried rice. For the most part, the portions are OKAY, but definately over the years they've downsized their portions. When I was younger, we would get a mountain of clams, and now I think at most there are about six.... Yeah... that doesn't sound too good. Overall, good for a quick and DECENT Chinese fix.
author: Julie L.

description: This is literally the worst restaurant that I have ever been to in my life.  The place is absolutely filthy, FILTHY.. I have no idea how they haven't been shut down.  Our glasses and dishware had dried food stuck to it, the carpets and walls are disgusting, and there were hundreds of tiny fruit flies swarming around us during our meal.  The service was terrible and the food was even worse.  The three of us that went ate a total of 6 bites before waiting 30 minutes to get our check.  I could go on and on, but I think that you get the point.  If you read this, and you still eat there, then you deserve the experience that you will have.  I literally just came home and joined YELP to warn the world about this restaurant.  I am going to go vomit now, thanks for reading.
author: Steve O.

description: In three words, the food at this place can be described as, cheap, greasy, and cheap.  This is not gourmet fare.  It is chinese comfort food, and its has some of the lowest prices you can find for a restaurant in the Sunset, which is already pretty low.  I come here with such great frequency, that the waitstaff(one of whom speaks english, along with the woman who takes the money) commented when I cut my hair.  I've never eaten inside, if only because I would be embarrassed to take a friend there, since the decor consists of dirty curtains, bare white walls with the occasional picture of one of those waterfalls where the water moves in some kind of screen.  How do those work, btw?  This restaraunt is like a guilty pleasure.  And I love it.  It's perfect for when you need food, need food now, and need food cheap.  You can feed yourself for a day and half one one order of 4.00 chow mein, which I highly reccomend.  It's on Taraval at 19th, next door to the Shannon Arms.  Big yellow awning.  Every sunseter should have them on speed dial.  Its like putting smiles into your belly, is one way to think about it.
author: Mike C.

description: I'm going to keep this short and simple.  This is not the type of restaurant where a maitre'd greets you and takes your coat at the door.  You'll be lucky if you get acknowledged right away by the wait staff.  Here you get large portions of consistently great tasting food that won't send you to the poor house.  Come here when you need a fixin of delicious greasy Chinese food not the service, ambiance, or cleanliness.
author: Amy T.

description: At half the price and five times the quality of a bowl of soup I ate recently at the Union Square tourist trap I was unfortunate enough to have burned my mouth on, why in the world can't a great little hole-in-tie-wall place like this be closer to where I work?  The comments on rats and insects are nonsense (though my table might have been wiped down a little more thoroughly before I arrived).  The fried fish was out of this world, the pork chop serving generous and tasty!  You can get away with just that bowl of wonton soup, though.  I'll be going back!
author: Sophie B.

description: I can say, this is a very good restaurant, it was such a bomb in San Francisco, and also it was very cheap, and the dishes are large. I can not find a res truant with this price in the whole bay area. As they say, they are really the king of restaurant in bay area. I just make it easy " The half price of the fast food, and you can get more full then the fast food. I don't care the environment because you have to understand, it was a old restaurant, how can you expect it every thing is new. If they are not good how can they survive. I recommend this restaurant because it is very good and with the cheapest price in bay area.
author: chin fai h.
